title: Choosing the right format for open data
displayTitle: Choosing the right format for open data
body:
The format of an open dataset is the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format enables simpler management and reuse of the data. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms that suit the user’s needs.

In this module we'll explore the following:
  • Why formats matter to open data
  • Choosing the correct structure
  • Access open data formats
  • Keeping it simple with CSV

title: Open data formats
body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains why formats matter in open data, how to choose the right structure and formats and why CSV is a good starting point for most tabular open data.

title: Usability, management and access
body: Open data must be available for anyone to access use and share. In this section we consider what formats maximise usability of the data, ease of access for everyone and makes management simple for publishers.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Usability
_items.body:
The most usable format for data is likely to be one in which the dataset was first created. In many cases, this format may be a proprietary software programme like Microsoft Excel. While such programmes often have the ability to export data in other formats, their popularity can make publishing in a different format a barrier to reuse by others.

Additionally, software programmes like Excel also come with richer content, like styling on tables and graphs of data. These can all help to give context to a human who is trying to understand the data.

_items.title: Management
_items.body:
For some publishers, open data is now the main source for their data, even for staff in the publishing organisation. Using open data as a way for staff to access information inside an organisation has many benefits:

  • Increases knowledge of team on open data.
  • Increases sustainability and trust of data by making it a key component of the organisation’s operations.
  • Creates clear opportiunities for innovation.

_items.title: Access
_items.body:
For open data to be as accessible as possible, it must be:

  • A format that the user can understand.
  • A format that machines can read.
  • A format that supports easy reuse of the data.
  • A format that doesn’t require expensive tools to access.

The format appropriate for each dataset may be different. A document (like a PDF) may make the data the easiest for a human to understand but would not be the most readable for a machine. For this reason, accessibility is often achieved by making the same data available in a range of different formats.

title: Common data structures
body: Not all data can be appropriately expressed as a spreadsheet. Different file formats may have to be considered. There are three key structures to be aware of: tabular, hierarchical and network.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Tabular
_items.body:
The most common structure is tabular. Data is organised into rows and columns listing sequential values, such as expenditure.

If the data is based on separate entries that are not linked to each other then a tabular file structure in a format such as CSV is ideal. An example of appropriate tabular data is the Italian data portal’s museum attendance figures.
Take me to Italian Data Portal

_items.title: Hierarchical
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data points, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country. If the dataset depends on the relationship between data points and follows a structure in which data points are linked in vertical ‘trees’, a hierarchical data structure in a format such as JSON is ideal. An example of appropriate hierarchical data is the business data from gov.uk.
Take me to the gov.uk business data

_items.title: Network
_items.body:
Network structured data allows relationships to exist between any combination of elements in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure are social networks. Think of your network of friends and their friends on Facebook, consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn.

The web is another example of a network data structure, where web pages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

title: Finding open data in the right formats
displayTitle: Finding open data in the right formats
body:
As a user of open data, it is important to understand how publishers are delivering different formats to you for reuse.

Not all data is suitable for download either because it is too large, too regularly updated or too complex to expose as static files. Some data may need to be split into smaller parts. Other data may need to be published as live feeds to make sure it stays in date.

_items.title: Downloadable open data
_items.body:
Tabular data is the most suited for download. This is why most government open data portals are predominantly tabular data. However managing millions of rows of data may require other considerations:

  • Should the data be split into smaller datasets?
  • How often should the data be updated?
  • How will changes in the way you publish affect the previous releases?

_items.title: Live data and data feeds
_items.body:
Some data is not suitable to be made available as a downloadable file.

Much of this data is updated so regularly that the file downloads would be too large for most users. This type of open data structure may be made available by a machine interface, also know as an API.

There are many services that make machine interfaces available over the web. These services can be directly integrated into other web applications. For an example of an open data API, look at the Belgian railway company.
Take me to iRail API

title: Choosing the right format for open data
displayTitle: Choosing the right format for open data
body:
When it comes to open data formats, start with CSV.

A comma separated values (CSV) file is simply lines of data with each data point separated from the next by a comma. CSV is perfect for tabular data and can be easily loaded into and saved from applications like Excel, making it accessible to users.

Although CSV doesn’t maintain formatting and graphs like Excel formats, it is an open, machine readable format. CSV represents the simplest format that still support broad reuse of open data. In other words, CSV is the ‘lowest common denominator’ for open data and should be welcomed wherever possible.

title: Open data formats
body:
The format of an open dataset is the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format enables simpler management and reuse of the data. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms that suit a user’s needs.

Wherever possible the CSV file format should be used for sharing open data. CSV is a simple to understand, highly reusable and machine readable format.
